questions.question: I might can be able to help.
questions.description: Can should be removed. The sentence should read: I might be able to help.

questions.question: I came as much quickly as I could.
questions.description: Before adjectives and adverbs, as is used without much.

questions.question: I donâ€™t care how much expensive that laptop is. I am going to buy it.
questions.description: Before adjectives and adverbs how is used without much.

questions.question: You are quite rather a nuisance.
questions.description: Quite and rather have very similar meanings. Use only one of them in a sentence.

questions.question: Do not talk such a nonsense!
questions.description: Such is used without a before uncountable nouns.

questions.question: I have been to quite too many countries recently.
questions.description: Quite should be removed. Quite cannot modify too many or too much.

questions.question: Most of people do not understand philosophy.
questions.description: We use most without of before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: I have read all six of novels by Jane Austen.
questions.description: Of is omitted before a noun without a determiner.

questions.question: Although I was not interested in the lecture, but I sat through it.
questions.description: Although and but have very similar meanings. Use only one of them in a sentence.

questions.question: Though he started early but he arrived last.
questions.description: Though and but have very similar meanings. Use only one of them in a sentence.

questions.question: It is a small house. Besides, it also needs a lot of repairs.
questions.description: Besides and also mean the same. Use only one of them in a sentence.

questions.question: I will never forget meeting you on that afternoon.
questions.description: Prepositions are not normally used before expressions beginning with next or last.
